title: Proxy doesn't work
content:
The proxy settings just don't apply. I set the settings on the system, all programs work via proxy except Firefox (set to use system proxy settings). If I set the proxy manually in Firefox, the connection still doesn't go through the proxy.

I found that only the very first connection after starting Firefox goes through the proxy, absolutely all subsequent connections do not go through the proxy.

title: Vyhledání záložek podle textu ale jen v jediné složce
content:
Mám ve složce Ostatní záložky asi tisíc záložek, možná víc. Potřebuju vyhledat ty, které mají v názvu slovo například "tanec" a dát si je do složky Tanec. Chápu, že to nebude přesně, ale to mi nevadí. Problém je v tom, že když zadám vpravo nahoře do vyhledávání slovo "tanec", vyhledají se mi nejen záložky ze složky Ostatní záložky, ale všechny uložené záložky ve všech !!! složkách. Čili - buď potřebuju

  • omezit vyhledávání jenom na aktuální zobrazenou složku, anebo
  • zadat do sloupců název složky, ve které se záložka nalézá.

Nic z toho neumím zařídit. A nezbývá než je třídit pomalu jednu po druhé.

Máte pro mě nějakou radu?

title: Release Management - Best Practises
content:
Title: Change Control/Releases Management - Best Practises

I spent many years in an IT shop and in control of QA and implementation of updates to the system. I found this description gives a reasonable definition of the issue - "Release management refers to the process of planning, designing, scheduling, testing, deploying, and controlling software releases. It ensures that release teams efficiently deliver the applications and upgrades required by the business while maintaining the integrity of the existing production environment." [opentext.com] Some of the critical success factors of updates dealt with predictability (frequency and advance scheduling of updates), planning, minimizing disruption to users and maintaining stability of the system. Even emergency fixes, had to assess the impacts and proceed accordingly. Good communication is always mandatory. It also has to be a cost-effective process that is acceptable to both IT and the users. If you do the research, you'll see that updates should be scheduled with a set frequency (i.e. monthly, weekly and possibly daily for certain types of changes but NOT ALL) and they are done at a set time of day (when usage is at its lowest to minimize disruption). To illustrate this, there should be a place that I can go to and see the key facts of your release management plan. It might say something like “updates are done weekly on Sundays at 3am ET. Here are the items that are scheduled to be implemented for the next year. I would be able to see every Sunday for the next year listed and under each date, would be a list of the changes that are to be implemented on that release date. Each item would be described clearly in business terms. It would also show me the history of what has been released in the past, and it should flag anything that was released on a day other than the expected date (ie Sundays at 3am).” Deviating from the set time introduces instability into the system and causes untold grief on users and is not cost-effective. If you are good at following best practises like these, you will find your costs decrease, your system is stabler, your users are happier, there is minimal, if any, disruption to users and more. It will be a benefit to all. I find that I am constantly being impacted by Firefox updates, very often at critical times when I cannot afford the time to deal with the disruption. It has been very disruptive and expensive for me. I find I never know when you will strike or what it is you are planning to implement. Just recently, I had to take time away from an important task to apply your update as my machine had become unstable because of your pending update. It was only a few hrs later, that I got notified there was another update ready to download and install. I elected not to download at that time yet you kept telling me there was a download. Once again, my machine became unstable and slowly ground to a halt and then crashed. I lost a ton of work. It's a huge setback. I always have issues as soon as you first put out that notification that an update is available. It shouldn't be impacting me and nothing on my machine should change until I choose to download and install the update. But that is not what happens. I've been burned far too many times. I cringe every time that notification appears as I know it means it won't end well. The timing and increased frequency of your updates is having a significant impact on my productivity. They seem to happen at any time of the day and on way too many days each week. They are corrupting my machine even when I elect to defer the download of the update. You need to be batching changes and installing them no less than once a week and at a time of traditionally low activity. I should know what your schedule is so I can plan accordingly. Based on my experience, I can only conclude that you have extremely poor release management procedures and perhaps no procedures. The communication is nonexistent until after the fact. It's far too little and far too late. My preference is to use Firefox, but I'm now at a point that I cannot continue to sustain the hits from what appears to be a release system that is not controlled and has no respect for the impacts on its users. Are you open to a discussion on how you can improve releases and would you be willing to work with users to define the requirements and implement changes that will provide a better user experience plus achieve many more benefits? I'm willing to share my knowledge and experience to help improve the situation if you are willing to dedicate some resources to improve this area of concern. I'm quite confident that we will all win if improvements and best practises are implemented. I expect it will have minimal IT costs and has potential for large gains in the user community. Please advise.
creator: acrae

title: Firefox has become almost unusable-- slow to load- hangs- not responding-etc.
content:
For the last several days, Firefox has become nearly unusable. It started using an excessive number of processes. Then I started getting very frequent hanging and "Mozilla Firefox (not responding). It may freeze for several minutes, and often I have to shut down and restart my PC. It then takes much longer than usual to shut down, and after restarting, it takes several tries to get Firefox to open. A couple days ago, I updated Firefox to the new version for Windows 7 Vista, and it may have actually gotten worse.

It took me about 25 minutes to type this short description of the problem because it froze several times.
